image.altText: A Bureau of Meteorology track map for the cyclone, showing it making landfall south of Borroloola

props.synopsis: The defence force has been called in to assist with evacuations as severe Tropical Cyclone Megan tracks towards the Northern Territory coast ahead of an expected crossing tonight.

title.children: ADF called in as Tropical Cyclone Megan on track to make landfall as category three

image.altText: A grand looking building is surrounded by palm trees.

props.synopsis: The NT government pledged to review systemic racism in every government agency three years ago, but so far only one department has been examined.

title.children: The NT government committed to reviewing systemic racism in 2021. The first report is still yet to be finalised

image.altText: A man standing by a plant in his office with his arms crossed.

props.synopsis: The ATO is chasing more than $34 billion in debts owed by small businesses and self-employed Australians that were put on hold during the pandemic, sending some businesses to the wall.

title.children: As the ATO comes 'out with a vengeance', more small businesses are going under

image.altText: Perth skies glow orange as a result of a bush fire in the hills.

props.synopsis: Most stories during WA's record-breaking heatwave last month didn't mention the health risks of extreme heat and the link with climate change, despite overwhelming scientific evidence, according to an analysis of how news outlets reported on the event.

title.children: 'Vaguely terrifying': When heatwaves hit my city, the media downplayed the role of climate change

image.altText: Extreme close up of Indigenous child's eye.

props.synopsis: South Australia's Department for Child Protection (DCP) has apologised over claims of "indefensible" practices of removing newborns from First Nations mothers shortly after birth, causing trauma to the mothers, families and health staff.

title.children: 'DCP workers actually entered the delivery room': Claims of 'indefensible' baby removals from First Nations mothers

image.altText: Serious looking woman facing camera, open patio structure in background, table, surfboard on wall, plants

props.synopsis: Lying on his bed 24 hours a day in complete darkness, Dan Harris's life is slipping away. His parents want money put into research to help the quarter of a million Australians with myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome.

title.children: Mother heartbroken as son 'loses everything' from chronic fatigue

image.altText: Peter Garrett sitting in a dark room lit by fairy lights with plants in the background.

props.synopsis: Midnight Oil frontman Peter Garrett says he's "surprised" to have the power, passion and energy to release new music at 70.

title.children: Why Peter Garrett refuses to let personal tragedy define him

image.altText: A small donkey stands inside a derelict building looking at the camera, illuminated by light streaming through a window.

props.synopsis: Daguragu was the first land handed back to Indigenous people by the Commonwealth, but the local economy has stalled. Here's why, and what's being done about it.

title.children: In this remote community, the former shops have gone to the donkeys, but there's hope for change

image.altText: Photo of Wiradjuri man Raymond Munro

props.synopsis: Exclusive data covering 4.3 million police searches has revealed a quota-driven culture that boosts search numbers at the risk of abusing police powers.

title.children: Raymond can't count how often he's been searched by police. Data reveals he's just one of millions

image.altText: Figurines with computers and smartphones are seen in front of the words "Artificial Intelligence AI" in this illustration.

props.synopsis: Before the government does anything to regulate and legislate AI, we need to have our own reckoning as a community about how we want to use this technology or face having those decisions made for us again, writes Patricia Karvelas.

title.children: A quiet revolution threatens to change everything in our lives, yet there's little national debate over it

image.altText: Close-up of woman sitting by window with a neutral expression, wearing a check button-up shirt.

props.synopsis: 'Escape funds' may seem less relevant than they were for our mothers and grandmothers, but some experts say they are common sense and a way to feel 'safer' in relationships.

title.children: Linda has an 'escape fund' in case her relationship goes south. Should you?

image.altText: Russian President Vladimir Putin speaks during a news conference.

props.synopsis: Vladimir Putin's grip on Russia's presidency has tightened after early results in an election, many claim was rigged, indicated he'd win almost 90 per cent of the vote — although not everything went his way.

title.children: Thousands turn up to vote against Putin in Russia and abroad

image.altText: Jar of Vegemite on wooden kitchen table with background blurred.

props.synopsis: A common ingredient in two Australian favourites — beer and Vegemite — could help break down and recycle e-waste.

title.children: How Vegemite can help break down your old computers, phones and TV sets

image.altText: Copy of AFL5QH

props.synopsis: The first full round of the 2024 AFL season delivered in spades, with some clubs already facing serious questions and others celebrating brilliant starts to their campaigns. Here are the biggest talking points from round one.

title.children: AFL Round-up: Horror start for flag favourites, Clarry's magic moment and Rowell's insane stats

image.altText: A man who has taken a selfie in front of a dirt mount wearing a hard hat.

props.synopsis: Skilled refugees come to Australia hoping to work in their chosen field, but often face a long and expensive process to get their qualifications recognised. As employers grapple with a worker shortage, these experts say it's a problem worth fixing.

title.children: Mohammed heard there was a shortage of engineers in Australia, but what he discovered was 'totally different'

image.altText: a house for sale in the brisbane suburb of stafford with the sale sign in the front yard

props.synopsis: Stamp duty is an unquestioned part of buying a home in Australia, making it easy to overlook how affordable homes would be without it and how many Australians would move if it wasn't there.

title.children: 100,000 more people would move house if stamp duty was scrapped in just one state

image.altText: A smart meter electricity reader installed on a weatherboard home.

props.synopsis: Having a technician come to your home to read your electricity meter is slowly becoming a thing of the past thanks to the rollout of smart meters. Here's how they work.

title.children: Can smart meters save you money? We asked the experts for their opinions

image.altText: An illustration of light globes featuring the face of Craig Souter

props.synopsis: Following a horror two years in energy markets, there had been hopes of price relief for consumers. Experts are warning people not to get their hopes up.

title.children: His last power bill sent single dad Craig into shock. This is how analysts like our chances of prices dropping

image.altText: Two brown and white birds with big open beaks

props.synopsis: Let's find out how well you know your backyard birds. Will you get the squawk of approval?

title.children: Quiz: Do you know your magpies from your rosellas and bin chickens?

image.altText: Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences winner Angus Deaton.

props.synopsis: A Nobel Prize-winning economist has criticised the foundations of mainstream economics, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: How economics has contributed to 'a mirror image of a Robin Hood society', according to someone who won its highest prize

image.altText: Russian soldiers pour sawdust on to road where a missile attack struck cars in Belgorod

props.synopsis: Russia accuses Ukraine of attempting to sabotage the last day of its elections by launching 35 drone attacks into the country.

title.children: Ukrainian drones attack Russian oil refinery and target Moscow on final day of election

image.altText: Tyler Byrnes wearing a black cap and green shirt smiling

props.synopsis: The Together Home program has housed 1,092 people across NSW since its inception during the height of COVID, with 74 per cent maintaining their tenancies – but its funding is due to run out in June.

title.children: Tyler says he became a 'new person' after using a NSW accommodation service. Its funding is yet to be renewed

image.altText: NSW Premier Chris Minns speaks to media during a press conference in Sydney

props.synopsis: Some of Australia's top legal and criminal justice experts accuse Premier Chris Minns of ignoring "years of evidence" after the government introduced a bill that would make it harder for young people to get bail.

title.children: 'You're starting a war': NSW Premier Chris Minns warned over proposed bail changes

props.synopsis: Brad Balzan died a violent death in his own backyard. Some are calling it "the worst outcome imaginable of proactive policing".

title.children: CCTV caught Brad's final moments before he was shot after being stopped for wearing a hoodie

image.altText: Steven Miles David Crisafulli with a red and blue background

props.synopsis: Labor would face an electoral wipe-out in Queensland if last weekend's by-election results were repeated in the October state election, but the LNP isn't taking anything for granted.

title.children: 'A kick in the pants with steel cap boots': What do two 'very bad' by-elections mean for Labor in Queensland?

image.altText: A woman wearing a hi viz jacket standing in front of a construction site

props.synopsis: Whether it's insults, derogatory remarks or being drawn into uncomfortable conversations, Australian workers are still facing sexual harassment. A new campaign aims to help employers step up.

title.children: 'Get off site and get back into the kitchen': Sexual harassment rife in Australian workplaces

image.altText: Female vets stand around an operating table with a cat.

props.synopsis: From letting them wait inside for the school bus to building cubbies in animal cages, one veterinary clinic is doing what it can for children to help their mums continue working.

title.children: There is not a man in sight at this vet clinic, but you might find some kids in cubby houses

image.altText: Inside the houseboat Bad Habits, inundated with water, with a couch floating in foreground

props.synopsis: Pensioner Ross Day says his houseboat was "a good idea at the time" when trying to find an affordable housing solution on the Sunshine Coast but wild weather turned his life upside-down.

title.children: Divorcee's sunken home to require 'specialist salvage' from Queensland river

image.altText: The outside of the Gabba stadium with crowds walking to and from.

props.synopsis: The results of an Olympic and Paralympic infrastructure review by former lord mayor Graham Quirk are due to be released publicly on Monday morning.

title.children: Olympic review urges scrapping Gabba rebuild for a more costly Victoria Park stadium

image.altText: Two Palestinian women and some young girls carry their belongings along a dirt road.

props.synopsis: The ABC understands a number of visa cancellations are now being reversed, with additional security and other checks conducted by Home Affairs now complete.

title.children: Home Affairs reverses visa cancellations for some Palestinians fleeing Gaza

image.altText: Sophie Allouache in a white dress and Penny Wong in a red blazer stand together smiling.

props.synopsis: Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong tied the knot with long-time partner Sophie Allouache in Adelaide on Saturday.

title.children: Foreign Minister Penny Wong weds partner in 'special day' in Adelaide

image.altText: Carley Ernst, Rebecca Cole and Lauren Jackson hold up their hands

props.synopsis: Lauren Jackson wins her sixth WNBL title as Southside Flyers crush the Perth Lynx in game three of the grand final series in Melbourne.

title.children: Flyers crush Lynx, Lauren Jackson wins sixth WNBL title

image.altText: Silhouttes of people watching as large red and orange smoke clouds rise from the ground.

props.synopsis: A volcano in Iceland has erupted for the fourth time in three months, sending orange jets of lava into the night sky.

title.children: Lava shoots into sky as Icelandic volcano erupts
